quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Which of the following is a Python tuple?
quiz.reason: Tuples are represented with round brackets.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Suppose t = (1, 2, 4, 3), which of the following is incorrect?
quiz.reason: Values cannot be modified in the case of tuple, that is, tuple is immutable.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output ofthefollowingPythoncode?

>>>t=(1,2,4,3)
>>>t\1:3]
quiz.reason: Slicing in tuples takes place just as it does in strings.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What is the data type of (1)?
quiz.reason: A tuple of one element must be created as (1,).

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: If a=(1,2,3,4), a[1:-1] is _________
quiz.reason: Tuple slicing exists and a[1:-1] returns (2,3).

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What type of data is: a=[(1,1),(2,4),(3,9)]?
quiz.reason: The variable a has tuples enclosed in a list making it a list of tuples.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Tuples can’t be made keys of a dictionary.
quiz.reason: Tuples can be made keys of a dictionary because they are hashable.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Which of these about a set is not true?
quiz.reason: A set is a mutable data type with non-duplicate, unordered values, providing the usual mathematical set operations.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Which of the following is not the correct syntax for creating a set?
quiz.reason: The argument given for the set must be an iterable.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: If a={5,6,7,8}, which of the following statements is false?
quiz.reason: The members of a set can be accessed by their index values since the elements of the set are unordered.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: If a={5,6,7}, what happens when a.add(5) is executed?

options.c: Error as there is no add function for set data type

options.d: Error as 5 already exists in the set

quiz.reason: There exists add method for set data type. However 5 isn’t added again as set consists of only non-duplicate elements and 5 already exists in the set. Execute in python shell to verify.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Which of these about a frozenset is not true?
quiz.reason: A frozenset is an immutable data type.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Set makes use of __________Dictionary makes use of ____________
quiz.reason: Set makes use of keys.Dictionary makes use of key values.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Input order is preserved in sets.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Which of the following functions cannot be used on heterogeneous sets?
quiz.reason: he functions sum, min and max cannot be used on mixed type (heterogeneous) sets. The functions pop, remove, update etc can be used on homogenous as well as heterogeneous sets. An example of heterogeneous sets is: {‘abc’, 4, (1, 2)}

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Which of the following functions will return the symmetric difference between two sets, x and y?
quiz.reason: he function x ^ y returns the symmetric difference between the two sets x and y. This is basically an XOR operation being performed on the two sets.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: The ____________ function removes the first element of a set and the last element of a list.
quiz.reason: The function pop removes the first element when used on a set and the last element when used to a list.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: The difference between the functions discard and remove is that:

options.a: Discard removes the last element of the set whereas remove removes the first element of the set

options.b: Discard throws an error if the specified element is not present in the set whereas remove does not throw an error in case of absence of the specified element

options.c: Remove removes the last element of the set whereas discard removes the first element of the set

options.d: Remove throws an error if the specified element is not present in the set whereas discard does not throw an error in case of absence of the specified element

quiz.reason: The function remove removes the element if it is present in the set. If the element is not present, it throws an error. The function discard removes the element if it is present in the set. If the element is not present, no action is performed (Error is not thrown).

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: If we have two sets, s1 and s2, and we want to check if all the elements of s1 are present in s2 or not, we can use the function:
quiz.reason: Since we are checking whether all the elements present in the set s1 are present in the set s2. This means that s1 is the subset and s1 is the superset. Hence the function to be used is: s2.issuperset(s1). This operation can also be performed by the function: s1.issubset(s2).

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?

x=set('abcde')
y=set('xyzbd')
x.difference_update(y)
x
y
quiz.reason: The function x.difference_update(y) removes all the elements of the set y from the set x. Hence the output of the code is:\n{‘a’, ‘c’, ‘e’}\n{‘x’, ‘y’, ‘z’, ‘b’, ‘d’}.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What will be the output of the following Python code, if s1= {1, 2, 3}?\n\ns1.issubset(s1)
quiz.reason: Every set is a subset of itself and hence the output of this line of code is true.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?
a=set('abc')
b=set('def')
b.intersection_update(a)
a
b
quiz.reason: The function b.intersection_update(a) puts those elements in the set b which are common to both the sets a and b. The set a remains as it is. Since there are no common elements between the sets a and b, the output is:

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.reason: The function isdisjoint returns true the two sets in question are disjoint, that is if they do not have even a single element in common. The two sets s1 and s2 do not have any elements in common, hence true is returned in both the cases.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.reason: The function s1|s2 as well as the function s1.union(s2) returns a union of the two sets s1 and s2. Hence the output of both of these functions is: {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8}.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What will be the output of the following Python code snippet?\nz=set('abc$de')\n'a' in z
quiz.reason: The code shown above is used to check whether a particular item is a part of a given set or not. Since ‘a’ is a part of the set z, the output is true. Note that this code would result in an error in the absence of the quotes.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code snippet?
z=set('abc')
z.add('san')
z.update(set(['p', 'q']))
z
quiz.reason: The code shown first adds the element ‘san’ to the set z. The set z is then updated and two more elements, namely, ‘p’ and ‘q’ are added to it. Hence the output is: {‘a’, ‘b’, ‘c’, ‘p’, ‘q’, ‘san’}

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What will be the output of the following Python code snippet?\nfor x in set('pqr'):\n\tprint(x*2)
quiz.reason:
The code shown above prints each element of the set twice separately. Hence the output of this code is:
pp
qq
rr

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What will be the output of the following Python code snippet?\n{a**2 for a in range(4)}
quiz.reason: The code shown above returns a set containing the square of values in the range 0-3, that is 0, 1, 2 and 3. Hence the output of this line of code is: {0, 1, 4, 9}.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What will be the output of the following Python function?\n{x for x in 'abc'}
quiz.reason: The first function prints each element of the set separately, hence the output is: {‘a’, ‘b’, ‘c’}. The second function prints each element of the set thrice, contained in a new set. Hence the output of the second function is: {‘aaa’, ‘bbb’, ‘ccc’}. (Note that the order may not be the same)

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: The output of the following code is: class<’set’>.\ntype({})
quiz.reason: The output of the line of code shown above is: class<’dict’>. This is because {} represents an empty dictionary, whereas set() initializes an empty set. Hence the statement is false.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code snippet?
a=[1, 4, 3, 5, 2]
b=[3, 1, 5, 2, 4]
a==b
set(a)==set(b)
quiz.reason: In the code shown above, when we check the equality of the two lists, a and b, we get the output false. This is because of the difference in the order of elements of the two lists. However, when these lists are converted to sets and checked for equality, the output is true. This is known as order-neutral equality. Two sets are said to be equal if and only if they contain exactly the same elements, regardless of order.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code snippet?
l=[1, 2, 4, 5, 2, 'xy', 4]
set(l)
l
quiz.reason: In the code shown above, the function set(l) converts the given list into a set. When this happens, all the duplicates are automatically removed. Hence the output is: {1, 2, 4, 5, ‘xy’}. On the other hand, the list l remains unchanged. Therefore the output is: [1, 2, 4, 5, 2, ‘xy’, 4].

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: The following Python code results in an error.\n\ns={2, 3, 4, [5, 6]}
quiz.reason: The set data type makes use of a principle known as hashing. This means that each item in the set should be hashable. Hashable in this context means immutable. List is mutable and hence the line of code shown above will result in an error.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What will be the output of the following Python code?\ns={2, 5, 6, 6, 7}\ns
quiz.reason: Duplicate values are not allowed in sets. Hence, the output of the code shown above will be a set containing the duplicate value only once. Therefore the output is: {2, 5, 6, 7}

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: Write a list comprehension for number and its cube for:\nl=[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]
quiz.reason: The list comprehension to print a list of cube of the numbers for the given list is: [x**3 for x in l].

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?
s={1, 2, 3}
s.update(4)
s
quiz.reason: The code shown above will result in an error because the argument given to the function update should necessarily be an iterable. Hence if we write this function as: s.update([4]), there will be no error.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What is the syntax of the following Python code?\n>>> a=frozenset(set([5,6,7]))\n>>> a

options.c: Error, not possible to convert set into frozenset

quiz.reason: The above piece of code is the correct syntax for creating a frozenset.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
Is the following Python code valid?
>>> a=frozenset([5,6,7])
>>> a
>>> a.add(5)

options.c: No, invalid syntax for add method

quiz.reason: Since a frozen set is immutable, add method doesn’t exist for frozen method.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?
>>> a={3,4,5}
>>> a.update([1,2,3])
>>> a

options.a: Error, no method called update for set data type

options.c: Error, list can’t be added to set

options.d: Error, duplicate item present in list

quiz.reason: The method update adds elements to a set.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?
>>> a={1,2,3}
>>> a.intersection_update({2,3,4,5})
>>> a

options.b: Error, duplicate item present in list

options.c: Error, no method called intersection_update for set data type

quiz.reason: The method intersection_update returns a set which is an intersection of both the sets.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?
>>> a={1,2,3}
>>> b=a
>>> b.remove(3)
>>> a

options.b: Error, copying of sets isn’t allowed

quiz.reason: Any change made in b is reflected in a because b is an alias of a.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?
>>> a={1,2,3}
>>> b=a.copy()
>>> b.add(4)
>>> a

options.d: Error, copying of sets isn’t allowed

quiz.reason: In the above piece of code, b is barely a copy and not an alias of a. Hence any change made in b isn’t reflected in a.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?
>>> a={1,2,3}
>>> b=a.add(4)
>>> b
quiz.reason: The method add returns nothing, hence nothing is printed.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?
>>> a={1,2,3}
>>> b=frozenset([3,4,5])
>>> a-b

options.b: Error as difference between a set and frozenset can’t be found out

options.c: Error as unsupported operand type for set data type

quiz.reason: frozenset({1,2})

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What will be the output of the following Python code?\n>>> a={5,6,7}\n>>> sum(a,5)

options.d: Invalid syntax for sum method, too many arguments

quiz.reason: The second parameter is the start value for the sum of elements in set a. Thus, sum(a,5) = 5+(5+6+7)=23.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question: What will be the output of the following Python code?\n>>> a={1,2,3}\n>>> {x*2 for x in a|{4,5}}
quiz.reason: Set comprehensions are allowed.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.reason: Duplicate elements in a+b is eliminated and the length of a+b is computed.

quiz.subject: Python

options.b: Error, no method called issubset() exists

quiz.reason: The method issubset() returns True if b is a proper subset of a.

quiz.subject: Python

options.d: Error, no method called issuperset() exists

quiz.reason: The method issubset() returns True if b is a proper subset of a.

quiz.subject: Python
quiz.question:
What will be the output of the following Python code?
>>> a=(1,2)
>>> b=(3,4)
>>> c=a+b
>>> c
quiz.reason: In the above piece of code, the values of the tuples aren’t being changed. Both the tuples are simply concatenated.
